ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set 
      
Specifies the input data set. This option is required. If you do not specify this option, you get a system error.

Syntax: OUTSTAT=SAS-data-set 
      
Writes the log likelihood and information criteria to an output data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set
          
Writes the decoding results to an output data set.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ESTIMATE | LEARN options;
      
The ESTIMATE statement specifies options that are related to parameter estimation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set
          
Writes the parameter estimates to an output data set.

Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set
          
Writes the evaluation results to an output data set.

Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set
          
Writes the filtering results to an output data set.

Syntax: ALPHA=number 
          
Sets the forecast confidence limit size, where number is between 0 and 1. When you specify this option, 
the upper and lower confidence limits define the 100α% confidence interval. By default, ALPHA=0.95, which 
produces 95% confidence intervals.

Syntax: BACK=number 
          
Specifies the number of observations before the end of the data at which the multistep forecasts begin. 
The number must be less than or equal to the number of observations minus the number of lagged regressors 
in the model. By default, BACK=0, which means that the forecasts start at the end of the available data.

Syntax: LEAD=number 
          
Specifies the number of multistep forecast values to compute. By default, LEAD=1, which means that a 
one-step-ahead forecast is performed.

Specifies that the (multistep) forecasts be done after each observation. When you specify this option, 
the BACK= option is ignored.

Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set 
          
Writes the forecasting results to an output data set.

Syntax: TIME=variable 
          
Specifies the temporal or sequential order of the observations.

Syntax: SECTION=variable 
          
If the cross-sectional time series data are modeled, you should specify the SECTION= option to 
identify the section of each observation.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: INITIAL equation, …, equation;

The INITIAL statement sets up the initial parameter values for nonlinear optimization when the 
maximum likelihood method or the maximum a posteriori method is applied to the estimation of 
the HMMs. Only one INITIAL statement is allowed. If you specify more than one equation, separate 
them with commas. Only equations are supported in the INITIAL statement; hence, the inequality 
comparison operators (<, <=, >, >=) and the distribution operator ~ are not supported in the 
INITIAL statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Requests that the initial state probability vector (ISPV) not be fixed to the stationary distribution 
of the Markov chain and be estimated instead. If you do not specify this option, the ISPV is fixed 
to the stationary distribution of the Markov chain.

Syntax: METHOD=value 
          
Requests the type of estimates to be computed. 

By default, METHOD=ML.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the maximum a posteriori estimates.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: NSTATE=number 
          
Specifies the number of hidden states. The number must be a positive integer. By default, NSTATE=2.

Syntax: TYPE=value 
          
Specifies the type of model of interest.  

By default, TYPE=GAUSSIAN.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax:  OPTIMIZE options;
          
The OPTIMIZE statement specifies options that are related to optimization.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ALGORITHM=value 
          
Specifies the optimization algorithm.

Syntax: FEASTOL=number 
          
Defines the feasible tolerance. The optimizer exits if the constraint violation is less than number 
and the scaled optimality conditions are less than the value of the OPTTOL= option. By default, 
FEASTOL=10^-6.

Syntax: MAXITER=number 
          
Specifies the maximum number of iterations in the optimization process. The number must be a nonnegative 
integer. By default, MAXITER=128.

Syntax: MAXTIME=t 
          
Specifies an upper limit of t seconds for the optimization process, including problem generation time 
and solution time. If you do not specify this option, the optimizer does not stop based on the amount 
of time elapsed. The value of t can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number 
that has the largest absolute value that your operating environment can represent.

Syntax: MSRANGE=number 
          
Defines the range, a positive number, from which each variable can take values during the sampling process 
in multistart mode. This option is ignored if MULTISTART=0.

Syntax: MULTISTART=0 | 1 
          
Specifies whether to enable multistart mode. In multistart mode (that is, when you specify MULTISTART=1), 
the local solver solves the problem from multiple starting points, possibly finding a better local minimum 
as a result. The computing cost in multistart mode might be huge. By default, MULTISTART=0; that is, multistart 
mode is disabled by default.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Multistart mode is disabled. This is the default.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OBJLIMIT=number 
          
Specifies an upper limit on the magnitude of the objective value. By default, OBJLIMIT=10^20.

Syntax: OPTTOL=number 
          
Defines the measure by which you can decide whether the current iterate is an acceptable approximation 
of a local minimum.

Syntax: PRINTITERFREQ=number 
          
Specifies how frequently to output the optimization process history. The number must be a nonnegative 
integer. If PRINTITERFREQ=0, no iterations are output. If PRINTITERFREQ=n and n is positive, the 
optimization process history is output every n iterations. By default, PRINTITERFREQ=0.

Syntax: PRINTLEVEL=0 | 1 | 2 | 3 
          
Specifies the print level. By default, PRINTLEVEL=0.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Suppresses output of the initial parameter values and objective value, the algorithm information, and the final parameter values and objective value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Outputs the initial parameter values and objective value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Outputs the initial parameter values and objective value, and the algorithm information.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Outputs the initial parameter values and objective value, the algorithm information, and the final parameter  values and objective value.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SEED=number 
          
Specifies a nonnegative integer to be used as the seed for generating random number sequences. 
You can use this option to replicate results from different runs.

Syntax: SOLTYPE=0 | 1 
          
Specifies whether the optimizer should return only a solution that is locally optimal.

By default, SOLTYPE=1.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Requests that the optimizer return a locally optimal solution, provided that it locates one.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Requests that the optimizer return the best feasible solution found, provided that its objective value is better  than that of the locally optimal solution found.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PRIOR parameter-name ~ distribution-function(arguments);

The PRIOR statement sets up the initial hyperparameter values in the prior distributions of the parameters 
when the maximum a posteriori method is applied to the estimation of the HMM. If you specify the maximum 
likelihood (ML) method, the PRIOR statement is ignored. You can specify only one PRIOR statement. If you 
specify more than one distribution, separate them with commas.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Indicates the initial state probability vector. The prior distribution for ISPV must be the 
Dirichlet distribution.

Indicates the mean and covariance parameters for the observation distributions in the Gaussian HMM. 
The prior distribution of the mean and covariance parameters for each state must be the normal-
inverse-Wishart (NIW) distribution.

Indicates the transition probability matrix. The prior distribution for TPM must be the 
Dirichlet distribution.

Indicates the Dirichlet distribution. There is one argument for the Dirichlet distribution, and it 
should be a valid matrix expression of the proper size.

Indicates the normal-inverse-Wishart (NIW) distribution. There are four arguments for the NIW 
distribution, and they should be valid matrix expressions of the proper size.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SCORE options;
      
The SCORE statement specifies options that are related to scoring data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: INMODEL=SAS-data-set 
          
Specifies the input data set for model information. The data set must be an output data set from the 
OUTMODEL= option in a previous call of the HMM procedure. When you specify this option, the ID, 
INITIAL, MODEL, OPTIMIZE, and PRIOR statements are ignored.

Syntax: OUTMODEL=SAS-data-set 
          
Writes the model information to an output data set. The output data set consists of binary large object 
columns to store the binary data. Do not edit the content of this output data set. If you run the PRINT 
procedure on this data set, you get a row of zeros because the data type of each column is binary.

Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set 
          
Writes the smoothing results to an output data set.
